Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2013 10:11PM - edited Aug 24, 2013 10:30PM by Shira Thank you everyone for the informative and helpful replies.  This site is a wealth of information! Reading and thinking a bit more, and going with my gut instinct, I feel like I would not be able to make a decision to have a mastectomy without more of a diagnostic reason to have one, especially since my primary reason for doing it would be to avoid radiation and the estrogen blocking medications, and it sounds like sometimes people still have to have/take those even with a mastectomy.  I am also glad that the lupectomy will give me additional results rather quickly, where researching the option of a mastectomy would slow the node biopsy (and margins diagnosis?) down.  I do feel like I am at a good (great) hospital with a competent doctor, and maybe if I had listened to doctors in the first place (I waited to get my first mammogram until I was 49!), they would have caught this even earlier.   So, I will go ahead with the Lumpectomy, but before I take radiation, medications, etc., I may get a second opinion, and I can meet with a genetic counselor afterwards if I would like to (no bc or ovarian cancer in my family but I am Jewish so it's possible I could test positive). So, thank you and I will keep reading!  Any additional thoughts are welcome! Shira P.S. Bessie, thanks for clarifying!  When I was mentioning the two choices, what I meant was that one choice was that I could have Lumpectomy and no radiation (with or without the estrogen blocking medications), but this is not what the doctor was recommending, just that taking or not taking the medications and/or having radiation is a personal decision.

Posts.Content: Shira wrote: Hello.  Everything is moving fast and I am confused, however, lurking on this forum has been helpful! I waited to have my first mammogram until I was 49 (no breast cancer in my familiy and thought I was so smart avoiding the "uneccesary" radiation).  This mammogram led to a second, which showed something suspicious, so I then had an ultrasound, needle biopsy, and after the results came back with IDC grade 1, 1.1cm, I also had an MRI, which luckily did not show anything more. So, I met with the surgeon today, and he said that the next step would be a Lumpectomy, with a node biopsy, and then radiation and estrogen (blocking?) medication (I am +, +. -).  I would like to avoid putting anything in me, so I asked about a mastecomy instead, and he said it was a very drastic (my words not his) procedure for something so small, and it seems like my two real choices are Lumpectomy with radiation (and estrogen blocking medicine), or Lumpectomy without Radiation (assuming the Node Biopsy is negative). He is a general surgeon but is part of a team that deals with Breast Cancer.  Also, he did not think I needed an Onco Test or that I will need Chemo. So my questions are this, is it common for a Lumpectomy/radiation to be recommended as the initial course without considering a mastectomy?  If I get a Lumpectomy now, can I change my mind and get a mastectomy later (and would it still be covered)?  Why might Chemo be recommended to some people with similar diagnosis but not to others?  Might radiation help short term survival more than long-term?  Should I have gotten a second opinion?  I cancelled one today and was planning to re-schedule once the node biopsy results come in. Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2013 03:26PM - edited Aug 28, 2013 03:33PM by Shira I just had a Lumpectomy yesterday and it was the first time I had anesthesia.  I tend to get nauseous very easily, motion sickness and things like that.  I was nauseous when I woke up after the surgery, but I don't they put the patch on me until I was already nauseous, and I am not sure how much of the nauseous feeling was from the anesthesia and how much from the Percustette (sp?).  At the time it was not a good feeling, and I had strange dreams when I tried to rest (in one dream I was sneaking a vitamin water!), but once I got up to go to the ladies room, and was moved into a reclining chair instead of lying in a bed, the worst of it went away pretty quickly.  Then for maybe another hour I stayed there and because I was a little dizzy they had to walk with me anywhere I wanted to walk (ladies room) to make sure I didn't fall.  Once I got home I felt pretty good, but I skipped the narcotic pain medicine as I did not want to take a chance of feeling nauseous again. Luckily I have been fine with just Tylenol. So, I agree with the people who said to try to get the patch ahead of time, and hopefully it will be manageble.  Good luck!
